result.execSummary:
The defendant Robert L Clemmerson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Theft-Business Setting <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(b).
  • Entry into/onto Bldg/Constuct.Site/Room, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.15(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  6/1/16.   COURT APPOINTED ATTORNEY FEES ADDED.  THEY ARE PAID IN FULL FROM ESCROW FUNDS.  Balance of escrow funds applied to the court costs.

Must seek and maintain employment which is satisfactory to your probation agent.  Defendant  must not leave or change employment without prior approval of your probation agent.  Must also continue to apply for social security disability benefits.

Until further order of the court, you shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person with the victims in this case or their business, The Depot in Merrillan, WI.

Must write a letter of apology which is approved by your probation agent to the victims, if agent deems appropriate.
Must comply with any recommendations for programming as requested by your probation agent.  Defendant must execute all releases of information for assessments, counseling, treatment, to allow probation agent to verify compliance.
Must submit a DNA sample and pay the surcharge.

timeConds.notes: Jail term is imposed and stayed.  No credit for time served.

Defendant appears in person with counsel Charles Betthauser.  Gerald Fox appears for the State.  DA Fox files an amended complaint:  adds Count 3 - Entry Into Locked Building.  Will plea to Count 2 & 3.  State has complied with victim notification and approve of the resolution.  Attorney Betthauser states he thought Count 3 would be Trespassing.  There is a joint recommendation for sentencing. Attorney Betthauser reviewed the amended complaint and waives the reading and wishes to proceed.  Judge reviews charges in amended complaint with defendant.  He states he understands.  Count 2 - pleas no contest; Count 3 - pleas no contest.  Judge reviews restitution request with defendant.  Court reviews guilty plea questionnaire/waiver of rights/elements of each charge.  Defense stipulates to facts in complaint that support the factual basis.  Court finds the pleas are FVI made and accepts plea/waiver of rights and finds defendant guilty of Counts 2 & 3.  Count 1 is dismissed and read-in.  Defendant does not excercise his right to allocution.  Court adopts the joint recommendation, withholds sentence and places defendant on probation for 2 years concurrent on each count with conditions of:  60 days jail imposed and stayed.  No contact with victims or their business.  Must write an apology letter if probation agent deems appropriate.  Must seek and maintain employment approved by agent and must also continue trying to attain SSI.  Must pay restitution plus surcharge.  Must pay costs of the action and supervision. Must submit a DNA sample and pay the surcharge.  Must report to probation today.
Witness List
Subpoena and Certificate of Appearance served on Chief M.J. to appear at 5/26 JT.

State's

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Attorney Betthauser appeared in person.  Judge Goodman and Court Reporter by telephone.  Jury trial still going.  Is #2 for May 26th.  May be rescheduled to 8/18 and 19.
from Attorney Betthauser to Judge Goodman
from DA to Judge Goodman
From DA Fox to Judge Goodman in response to defense's Motion for In-Camera Inspection

Attorney Betthauser is requesting victim's business financial records as an in camera review.  Betthauser states the DA is not in possession of these records.  States his client was paid cash when he did work for the victim.  The records will not become public record per Betthauser.  Unable to present defense without this information.  This shouldn't delay the trial.   DA Fox states he cannot order the victims to turn over their business records.; he can only use exculpatory evidence.  Court states he's done research on cases listed in the Motion.  Court questions attorney Betthauser.  Attorney Betthuaser states his requesting 3 weeks before and 3 weeks after is a reasonable amount of time.  DA States his argument against; total of 6 weeks is unreasonable.  Betthauser states he's open to any amount of time before and after the alleged incident.  Court asks for clarification of what he is to be looking for.  Attorney Betthauser states what specifics he's wanting the Court to review in the evidence.  The Court states this isn't supported by any type of affidavit and/or evidentiary showing.  Court requests input/argument from DA Fox.  Further argument by attorney Betthauser.  Court will order that the victims provide for the in camera review the record they have that will establish on March 11, 2005 that on March 12 or March 13, 2005 there was ? dollars locked in their safe.  DA Fox will notify the victims.  Court will examine that evidence and will notify the parties.  Status to be set in January through judical assistant.
Defendant's Motion for in Camera Inspection.
